Comment:
Both alienable and inalienable possession are expressed in the same way. Howeverr, when the possessed noun begins with a vowel, inalienable nouns have /n/ occuring between the possessive pronoun
and the noun, for  alienably possessed nouns, /h/ may occur. The inserted consonant, /n/ or /h/, is optional, and in the event it is absent, a
glottal stop is inserted instead, a productive phonological process
subject pronouns end in -a, different set of non-subject pronouns

the words which express temporal and spatial relations are analyzed as verbs, since they
take verbal morphology and occur in the same syntactic positions as verbs.

Suggested standardised comments: Not mentioned, The markers are treated as bound to the noun, The adpositions are often also lexical nouns and verbs
